user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1Result:
```c
static enum SHA1_RESULT
SHA1Result (struct SHA1Context *context, unsigned char
            Message_Digest[SHA1HashSize])
{
  int i;

  if (! context || ! Message_Digest)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_NULL;
  }
  if (context->corrupted)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  if (! context->computed)
  {
    SHA1PadMessage (context);
    for (i = 0; i < 64; ++i)
    {
      context->message_block[i] = 0;
    }
    context->length_low = 0;
    context->length_high = 0;
    context->computed = 1;
  }
  for (i = 0; i < SHA1HashSize; ++i)
  {
    Message_Digest[i]
      = (unsigned char) (context->intermediate_hash[i >> 2]
                         >> 8 * (3 - (i & 0x03)));
  }
  return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function SHA1Result:
#define SHA1HashSize 20
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in the function are invariant under Rule 14.3. Specific reasoning:
- The if statements (if (!context || !Message_Digest), if (context->corrupted), if (!context->computed)) depend on pointer values or structure fields; their truth values can vary and are not invariant.
- The for loops (for (i = 0; i < 64; ++i) and for (i = 0; i < SHA1HashSize; ++i)) use the loop variable i in the controlling expressions; i is modified by the loop, so the conditions are not invariant even though the upper bounds are compile-time constants (64 and SHA1HashSize). A constant bound does not make the controlling expression invariant when it depends on a changing variable.
- There are no while or do-while loops with constant controlling expressions, and no explicit infinite-loop constructs relying on an invariant condition that would need the exception.

Accordingly, there are no code fragments that require further investigation for Rule 14.3 in this function.
